clinical_study.brief_title: Time Restricted Feeding on Nonalcoholic Fatty Liver Disease
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Time-Restricted Feeding on Nonalcoholic Fatty Liver Disease in Obese Adults: a Randomized Clinical Trial

lead_sponsor.agency: Nanfang Hospital of Southern Medical University

clinical_study.source: Nanfang Hospital of Southern Medical University

brief_summary.textblock: Time restricted feeding (TRF) is a novel type of intermittent calorie restriction diet that involves eating a daily period of 8 hours or less. This is a randomized controlled trial to evaluate the effect of time restricted feeding (TRF) on hepatic fat contents and cardiometabolic risk factors in obese adults over 6 months compared to continuous energy restriction (CER).

primary_outcome.description: Intrahepatic fat content will be assessed by MR mDixon-Quant

secondary_outcome.description: Liver fiber will be assessed by liver Fibrotouch
Visceral fat will be assessed by abdominal CT scan
Body fat will be assessed by whole-body dual x-ray system
Insulin sensitivity will be assessed by HOMA-IR
β cell function will be assessed by HOMA-β

secondary_outcome.measure: Depression measured by the Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9)
Quality of sleep measured by the Pittsburgh sleep quality index (PSQI)
Quality of life measured by the 12-item Short-Form Health Survey Questionnaire (SF-12)

intervention.description: Participants will receive a diet of 1500-1800kcal/d for men and 1200-1500kcal/d for women during a window of 8 h/d (8 am to 4 pm).
Participants will follow receive a diet of 1500-1800kcal/d for men and 1200-1500kcal/d for women, without restriction on feeding time.
